history.content:
from the Data Science Computational Biology domain emphasis list of upper division classes:

  • BIO ENG 131. Introduction to Computational Molecular and Cell Biology (4 units) [BIOLOGY 1A, MATH 53]

  • BIO ENG 144. Introduction to Protein Informatics (4 units)

  • BIO ENG 145. Intro to Machine Learning in Computational Biology (4 units) [COMPSCI 61B, COMPSCI 70, COMPSCI 170]

  • COMPSCI 176. Algorithms for Computational Biology (4 units) [COMPSCI 70, COMPSCI 170]

  • MATH 127. Mathematical and Computational Methods in Molecular Biology (4 units) [MATH 53, MATH 55]

  • MCELLBI 137L. Physical Biology of the Cell (3 units)

  • MCELLBI 146. Topics in Computational Biology and Genomics (4 units) [CS 61A or equivalent]

  • INTEGBI 161. Population and Evolutionary  Genetics (4 units) [BIO 1A, BIO 1B, MATH 10A/16A]

----

Helpful handout Nicole linked a couple years ago: https://d1b10bmlvqabco.cloudfront.net/attach/hyq0br1u3kx7dg/icdxydvnk125h8/imm8fox9dtwb/Compbio_handout.pdf

----

Here's a spreadsheet of relevant courses that Prof. Yosef (who has previously taught 176) linked to us last sem!

children.subject: Also in Spring 2020: CS 294-150 - Machine Learning and Statistics Meet Biology with Jennifer Listgarten

thanks to everyone who has responded!! is a machine learning course pretty "essential" for computational biology? 189 sounds quite intimidating given my not-so-great relationship with math, so I might consider data100/data102 or bioe145. any thoughts?

history.content: I'm really interested in computational biology though don't have nearly enough time in my schedule to fit in the lower div chem/bio requirements to a lot of the upper div mcb courses. Are there any courses (besides cs176, I really wanted to take it but it's unknown when it'll be offered again) that are more application based and do not rely on a heavy biology background?
history.subject: classes related computational biology
